The reason why a lot of people watch this show is the same reason for reading a really depressing post-apocalyptic book series: once it's started, it had to be finished.  However, this season is an extreme drag.  Many people just want to see what happens with the main male and female leads: instead, the whole thing with the new kid is a ridiculous, numbing distraction.  Oh, that kid...that FREAKIN' ANNOYING kid...The characters, at this point, are not interesting.  The entire show is filled with extremely annoying moments (such as bad parenting and spoiled childen who need to be placed in a cellar to keep their whining to themselves) that reflect the notion that all the characters (including the city) are depraved, listless, irresponsible people, but the last season highlights this most brightly.  Moody conveys a most telling line in this season: "How can I be in the doghouse with a woman I'm not even f-ing dating, and why do I even care?"  Indeed - why should anyone watching this show care?  This is a perfect line of reasoning for people who watch this train derail very, very slowly in its last moments.  That is a good way to describe the whole show actually: a train losing contact with the rail, from beginning (in the distance) to end (close up), all in slow motion.

And it's so damn depressing.  Oh, soooooo depressing.

On what basis can you judge the Californication series? After all, it's not like you are watching the show expecting The Wire or even Community. Californication is basically Sex & the City for writers (just like Entourage is Sex & the City for bros and Girls is Sex & the City for women under 35) where charmingly amoral people get to act like children without responsibilities and a ton of easily accessed sex and narcotics that never quite leave a lasting impact (unless it's time to write a very minor character off the show). The viewer can live vicariously through Hank Moody and his even whackier friends as long as they know that its a wish-fulfillment fantasy. So judging Californication for being trite, superficial and celebrating smug jerks is missing the point. Besides, David Duchovny is a decent actor who can make Hank Moody - a man who would be utterly reprehensible in real life - rather charming.

I wanted to give this season a 3-star review since there were several aspects that felt forced and trite, but then I remember that I rather like the show's weaknesses and I have to judge the show based on Californication standards and somehow the series never fails to entertain me. And without the "final season" designation, there is really no way to see this season as that much different than the rest. It again ends with a hopeful sign that he might get back with Karen but he will mess up. The reconciliation scene even has a cranky lady changing her seat on an airplane and yelling at them so we just know not to expect sentimentality no matter how much Elton John is playing.

Yet there are some definite flaws this season. While there are flaws in every season (mangina, anyone?), this season seems to be saddled with the notion that Cousin Oliver was cool so Hank gets a long lost son in Levan who is not a character so much as a series of shouts and ticks that are supposed to be funny but fall flat. Michael Imperioli and Heather Graham come in for their supporting roles and they are both funny. Mary Lynn Rajskub is wasted in a thankless role as a crazy writer who wants better representation and the tv show within the tv show is terrible.

The main weakness hits around episode 9 when Karen gets in a car accident and Hank rushes to the hospital. She's fine (of course) but now she is bringing in the rank sentimentality. Natasha McElhone can be the series MVP for spending seven seasons playing a woman who is shocked and disgusted with Hank's shenanigans even though there should be a point where she just expects them. While Karen is supposed to be the anchor that keeps Hank sane, often Becca performed that role while Karen was the killjoy who wandered into the show from the real world to remind the audience that people are not expected to behave this way (which just ruins the fantasy - see also Skylar from Breaking Bad who really should have been the only likeable character on that show).

So what happens is that we are stuck with a third of the season devoted to Karen and Hank talking about their relationship while sad music plays in the background. This material is expected in Californication but it shouldn't be too dominant.

The final season of "Californication" managed to recapture the heart and soul of what made Hank Moody and his tale so much fun to watch over the years (beyond the gratuitous nudity ;-) ).  After an utterly bland and directionless sixth season, where he toured with the completely uninteresting, washed-up rock star, Atticus Fetch, Hank returned home to continue his quixotic quest to win the heart of his true love, Karen, and also get his life together.

  It would not be a Hank Moody story if there weren't several Hank-induced obstacles.  Among them include finding out about an unknown son, whom he fathered before he met Karen (and he looks like Jonah Hill); a reputation that leaves him with the only employment opportunity being a writer on tv show that is clearly going to be short-lived; and an increasingly estranged relationship with his daughter, Becca.

  This final season is enjoyable because you still understand why Hank pines for Karen so much (and why she can't 'quit' him); which is helped through a series of flashback scenes that show the two of them during the seemingly (but not exactly) happier early days, along with a still happily married Charlie Runkle and Marcy.  Seeing how Charlie and Marcy deal with finally be remarried is also entertaining.  I think Evan Handler has been vastly under-appreciated in his role as Charlie Runkle.  Evan has had to tap into a bit of fearlessness in order to play such flawed, and embarrassing, character, while still making you root for him.

  Funny, and moving, guest spots by Michael Imperioli, Heather Graham and Mary Lynn Rajskub also add to a fond farewell to Hank Moody.  It allows one to look back with good memories over the show's run.

For the last few seasons, I've been lamenting the sense that CALIFORNICATION, a show that I initially really found hilarious, surprisingly moving, and very ascerbic, kept getting away from that initial season in favor of ridiculous plots, and basically making Hank Moody more sympathetic despite how grotesque his behavior was becoming. Showrunner Tom Kapinos and star David Duchovny seemed to want you, with each passing season, to actively like an extremely unlikable character and root for his Peter Pan complex as he went around having sex with as many women as possible, doing as many drugs as possible and hanging around with as many sordid and sleazy people as possible. With the show's final season, though, they lowered the bar for the show so low that it was flat-out impossible to be even vaguely entertained by it.

We pick up where we left off with Hank running from his rock opera job to tell baby mama Karen that he loves her and wants only her. This, of course, backfires. He's now jobless again and stuck in L.A. with Charlie (Evan Handler) and Marcy (Pamela Adlon), trying to rekindle their marriage. Meanwhile a strange young man Levon (Oliver Cooper) is looking to interview him for his college paper, and when he's actually able to confront Hank, Levon reveals he's his son from a relationship with Julie (Heather Graham) who came before Karen. Hank, reeling from this and also from being hired to work on a hacky cop TV show with a series of alternately dysfunctional writers and their volatile producer (Michael Imperioli), begins doing all the dumb things again while still trying to instill faith in Karen that they belong together. The B-story of the season revolves around Charlie and Marcy and their declining financial situation and how Marcy's ex Stu (Stephen Tobolowsky) is ready to rectify that by giving them a million dollars to have sex with Marcy one last time. Hank and Karen's daughter Becca (Madeline Martin) is barely anywhere to be found for most of the season and provides the deus ex machina that will force Hank to choose a lonely life of debauchery, or a life with Karen.

There are almost too many problems with this season to list. First and foremost is the character of Levon as played by Oliver Cooper, who seems like a very low-rent Jonah Hill. He's written as a manic, freakish, moronic, socially retarded mama's boy that somehow is supposed to be endearing to Hank. Julia is a freakishly enabling mother who sets very few limits for Levon (limits that should be set for an 11-year-old, let alone a college-age boy), but also is undeniably attracted and attractive to Hank. It doesn't help either that Heather Graham, while being beautiful, is a terrible and uninteresting actress and does nothing with her role. The most unforgivable sin, though, is how little they do with all of the characters. No one changes. No one advances or goes backwards. There's no tension. Every performer, particularly Duchovny, has become a parody of themselves. I actually skipped quite a few episodes because everything was just so frustratingly uninteresting. The series finale is just so insultingly hacky that it almost erases everything that was once good about the show. Of this season, the only performer that seems to make it relatively unscathed is Adlon, who still is capable of bringing a lot of energy to her role. Duchovny, an actor with a penchant for seeming somewhat unexpressive, seems to be utterly sleepwalking throughout this final season.

Like HBO's TRUE BLOOD, another show that started out as something cool and overstayed its welcome by about three seasons, CALIFORNICATION's final season is easily its worst, and we can all just thank our lucky stars that someone put this dying show out of its misery.
